title: Pearl barley
text:
Pearl barley, or pearled barley, is <a href="barley">barley</a> that has been processed to remove its fibrous outer <a href="Hull%20%28botany%29">hull</a> and polished to remove some or all of the <a href="bran">bran</a> layer.
It is the most common form of barley for human consumption because it cooks faster and is less chewy than other, less-processed forms of the grain such as "hulled barley" (or "barley <a href="groats">groats</a>", also known as "pot barley" and "Scotch barley"). Fine <a href="barley%20flour">barley flour</a> is prepared from milled pearl barley.
Pearl barley is similar to wheat in its caloric, protein, vitamin and mineral content, though some varieties are higher in <a href="lysine">lysine</a>. It is used mainly in soups, stews, and <a href="potage">potage</a>s. It is the primary ingredient of the Italian dish <a href="orzotto">orzotto</a> and one of the main ingredients of the Jewish dish <a href="Cholent">Cholent</a>.
